report_title: IBISWorld | Automobile Wholesaling in the US Aug 2024
executive_summary: Automobile wholesalers consist of merchant distributors of new and used automobiles, light trucks, SUVs, heavy trucks, motorcycles, trailers, buses and motor homes. Motor vehicle parts or tire sellers are not included in this industry. Along with the broader automotive sector, wholesalers have endured volatile supply chains and economic conditions. During the pandemic, new car sales plummeted and people traveled less, contributing to weak revenue growth. Despite poor consumer markets, torrid growth across shipping and e-commerce industries stimulated demand for larger cargo vehicles. Overall, revenue strengthened at an expected CAGR of 0.1% to $823.3 billion through the current period, including a 0.7% increase in 2024, where profit fell to 3.2%. Growth will hasten through the outlook period. Strengthening economic conditions, highlighted by per capita disposable income growth and more positive consumer sentiment, will encourage consumers to spend more. This trend will lead to more new car purchases and push consumers to trade up to more expensive vehicles. Changing environmental standards and government support will also change the automotive landscape. The rollout and adoption of electric vehicles will force wholesalers to update inventories to appeal to consumer preferences. Rebates and tax breaks on more fuel-efficient cars will make them more popular. Overall, revenue will climb at an expected CAGR of 1.6% to $889.4 billion through the outlook period, where profit will reach 3.2%

current_performance.current_performance_point_description: The automotive supply chain struggled in 2020 during the pandemic. Economic uncertainty and low consumer confidence deterred new and used car purchases despite near-zero interest rates. Fewer new car sales heavily contributed to limited demand. Similarly, stay-at-home orders discouraged most households from traveling, decreasing vehicle wear and tear. In general, consumers were less likely to travel and purchase new vehicles during the period.

current_performance.current_performance_point_title: E-commerce growth supported demand from business markets
current_performance.current_performance_point_description: Businesses represent a minor but vital demand source for automobile wholesalers. Business markets primarily include shipping and transportation companies that purchase medium and heavy-duty trucks. Skyrocketing e-commerce markets have necessitated more domestic and international shipping, encouraging trucking and shipping companies to upgrade and expand their existing vehicle fleets. The growth of the freight transportation services index has highlighted the enhanced need for trucks.

current_performance.current_performance_point_title: Used car markets surged following the pandemic
current_performance.current_performance_point_description: New car sales typically overshadow used car markets since new cars are significantly more profitable. However, amid skyrocketing new car prices in 2021 and 2022, limited new car supply encouraged households and consumers to shop for used rather than new cars. This trend led to sizable increases in the used car market and historic resale value. Successful wholesalers jumped on changing markets and added more used vehicles to inventories.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: More strict government standards, including CAFE standards, have pushed automakers to create more fuel-efficient and fully electric vehicles. Wholesalers will stock more EVs and hybrids; these vehicles often cost more, potentially leading to higher purchasing costs and lower profit. However, various rebates and other programs may help wholesalers close the gap, aiding profit. The success of this transition largely depends on consumer preferences and EV charging availability.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: Government spending will indirectly support wholesalers
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: New infrastructure spending will profoundly impact the automotive and transportation sectors. For example, increasing public transportation funding will spur local government demand for buses. Spending for roadway improvements will also encourage driving activity, creating demand for automobile wholesalers. Similarly, the Infrastructure Investment and Jobs Act (IIJA) has allocated funding for EVs. Specifically, the federal government has allocated significant funding toward charging infrastructure alongside tax breaks, rebates and other discounts for businesses and households purchasing electric vehicles.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: Normalizing supply chains will stabilize profit
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: Volatile input costs caused by the pandemic and the Russian invasion of Ukraine will wane through the outlook period, making car prices relatively more stable and predictable. Wholesalers will be able to better predict purchasing expenses and adapt accordingly. Similarly, lower crude oil prices will encourage consumers to drive more, increasing demand for new cars. Lower fuel prices may also encourage households to purchase larger cars, like SUVs and minivans, indirectly boosting revenue for wholesalers.

industry_definition: Automobile wholesalers consist of merchant distributors of new and used automobiles, light trucks, SUVs, heavy trucks, motorcycles, trailers, buses and motor homes. Motor vehicle parts or tire sellers are not included in this industry.

opportunities: High Performance Drivers: Per capita disposable income
threats: Low Outlier Growth: Business sentiment index

key_trends: Allocate products and/or services to areas of greatest need

demand_determinants.determinant_description: Automobile wholesaler and manufacturers aim to have a customer base they can keep supplying over time as their automobiles become obsolete.

demand_determinants.determinant_title: Operate in a location that is close to key markets
demand_determinants.determinant_description: Most wholesalers prioritize access to key buyers. This trend leads to a high concentration of wholesalers in populated regions with strong disposable incomes.

business_locations.location_description: Most automobile wholesalers operate in highly populated regions. They compete to access the most populated and affluent markets, emphasizing regional demand.
Most automobile wholesalers operate in highly populated regions. They compete to access the most populated and affluent markets, emphasizing regional demand.
Most automobile wholesalers operate in highly populated regions. They compete to access the most populated and affluent markets, emphasizing regional demand.
Most automobile wholesalers operate in highly populated regions. They compete to access the most populated and affluent markets, emphasizing regional demand.
Many automobile wholesalers have distribution and storage facilities near automakers. This trend contributes to a higher concentration of wholesalers in the Great Lakes and Plains regions.

regulations_points.regulation_description: Wholesalers must comply with environmental regulations related to vehicle emissions, hazardous material handling and waste disposal. Regulations have tightened over time, increasing compliance costs.
Automobile wholesaling operations are labor-intensive, so companies must follow wage, hour and safety regulations that protect workers. Violations can result in penalties.

barriers_points.barrier_description: Most states require wholesalers to obtain licenses to store and distribute new and used vehicles. Wholesalers must also follow workplace safety standards.

Facilities and equipment represent major startup costs. Wholesalers must rent or purchase large warehouses to store products. Inventory acquisition costs also present a major barrier for many automobile wholesalers.

factors_increased_barrier: Licensing requirements in most states to operate as an automobile wholesaler
High startup costs for facilities, equipment and inventory acquisition

basis_points.basis_description: Wholesalers compete to offer cost-effective and time-efficient storage and distribution. Wholesalers must obtain varied inventories to appeal to buyer preferences. Companies with purchasing agreements from reputable automakers also have a competitive advantage.

Companies rely on regular inventory purchases, increasing capital expenses. Larger wholesalers have also integrated new technology to streamline inventory management, contributing to higher capital expenses.

concentration_points.concentration_description: Large-sized wholesalers can more easily invest in technology to support better purchase decisions and streamline costs, providing economies of scale. Leading wholesalers often have more varied inventories, which also appeals to a wider range of buyers.

concentration_points.concentration_title: Vertically integrated wholesalers maintain prominent positions
concentration_points.concentration_description: The most prominent automobile wholesalers are part of vertically integrated supply chains. Most major domestic and international automakers, like Ford, Toyota, Stellantis and GM, have distribution facilities across the country to better access local markets.

cost_factors.cost_factor_title: Purchases are the largest expense for automobile wholesalers
cost_factors.cost_factor_description: Purchases include new and used automobiles, light trucks, medium and heavy-duty trucks, RVs, buses and motorcycles. Wholesalers primarily purchase inventories from vehicle manufacturers and other wholesalers. Wholesalers face intense price competition, making minimizing purchase costs a crucial strategy to increase profit. Car prices have skyrocketed amid supply chain disruptions, though wholesalers have mostly managed to pass costs onto retailers and consumers. Used car markets also surged following the pandemic, causing used car prices to balloon. Many automobile wholesalers stocked more used vehicles to take advantage of this trend and increase inventory turnover.

Wholesalers have increasingly integrated new technologies, like inventory management systems and warehouse automation, to streamline a wide range of low-wage positions and cut costs. This practice will support long-term profit. For example, companies have purchased automated guided vehicles to move inventory. Regardless, companies have hired more skilled workers to monitor new software and automated technology. Companies also often hire seasonal demand to handle peak car buying seasons.

Automobile wholesalers generate slim but consistent returns. Wholesalers often rely on rapid inventory turnover to generate returns; sunk inventory costs, especially during periods of poor economic growth, pose a major threat to profit. Companies have also dealt with skyrocketing car prices; while most wholesalers successfully passed higher costs onto buyers, average profit has declined. Automakers, particularly Tesla, have also increasingly sold products directly to retailers or consumers. This business model has put more stress on wholesalers' profit.

capital_intensity_points.capital_intensity_title: Wholesalers require significant storage and transportation assets
capital_intensity_points.capital_intensity_description: Automobile wholesalers require large warehouses and storage facilities to house vehicle inventories. Companies also need fleets of trucks and trailers to transport vehicles between locations. While these assets are expensive, wholesalers can spread costs across high sales volumes.

To remain competitive, many wholesalers have invested in warehouse automation, inventory management software and other technologies. These investments have increased capital intensity but are expected to boost long-term profitability.

volatility_points.volatility_title: Revenue is tied to economic conditions
volatility_points.volatility_description: Demand for automobiles is highly cyclical and closely tied to overall economic performance. During recessions and periods of weak consumer confidence, demand for new and used vehicles plummets, significantly reducing wholesaler revenue.

volatility_points.volatility_title: Supply chain disruptions have caused volatility
volatility_points.volatility_description: Recent supply chain issues stemming from the COVID-19 pandemic have caused major volatility for automobile wholesalers. Vehicle production was disrupted, leading to inventory shortages that limited sales. At the same time, demand surged as the economy recovered, causing prices to spike.

technological_change_points.technological_change_description: Many wholesalers have adopted warehouse automation technologies like automated guided vehicles and inventory management software. While adoption has been moderate so far, the trend toward automation is expected to continue.

The growing popularity of electric vehicles (EVs) will require wholesalers to adapt their operations. EVs have different storage, transportation and maintenance requirements compared to traditional vehicles.

FAQs.question: What is the largest cost for automobile wholesalers?
FAQs.answer: Purchases, which account for 82.7% of revenue.

FAQs.question: How have profit margins trended for automobile wholesalers?
FAQs.answer: Automobile wholesalers have endured low profit margins, facing volatile supply chains, uneven demand and fluctuating economic conditions that have prevented profit growth.

FAQs.question: What trends have impacted costs for the industry?
FAQs.answer: Key trends impacting costs include: 1) Purchases being the largest expense, with wholesalers facing intense price competition; 2) Increasing automation to cut labor costs; 3) Slim but consistent profit margins that are threatened by sunk inventory costs during poor economic periods.

FAQs.question: What are some key financial ratios and benchmarks for the industry?
FAQs.answer: Some key ratios include: Profit margin of 3.2% (higher than sector average), average wage of $96,055 (higher than sector), EBIT/Revenue of 10% for 2022, leverage ratio of 6.3 in 2022, current ratio around 2.5-3 in recent years.
